instruction: Can the spectral changes picked up by different sets of remote sensing (RS) plant traits be used to effectively capture the spatial dynamics of Xylella fastidiosa (Xf) spread and improve the management of plant disease epidemics?
Output: Yes, the spectral changes picked up by different sets of remote sensing (RS) plant traits can be used to effectively capture the spatial dynamics of Xylella fastidiosa (Xf) spread and improve the management of plant disease epidemics. The research demonstrates that RS sensors can detect distinct spectral features in Xf-infected olive trees in the visible and infrared regions. By integrating remote sensing with a spatial spread model and a support vector machine (SVM) model, the study was able to predict the probability of Xf infection and accurately map the spatial distribution of the disease. The best performing RS-SVM model included predictors such as leaf protein content, nitrogen indices, fluorescence, thermal indicators, pigments, and structural parameters. By coupling the RS model with an epidemic spread model, the accuracy of disease prediction was further increased. The combined RS-spread model yielded higher accuracy compared to visual inspections and RS-only models, demonstrating the potential of remote sensing in improving the management of plant disease epidemics.
